thread.title: Federation Centres considers new retail fund
thread.title_full: Federation Centres considers new retail fund

title: Federation Centres considers new retail fund
text:
The Glen in Melbourne is part of Federation Centres' extensive portfolio of retail properties.
The newly merged retail landlord Federation Centres is undertaking a review to create a new unlisted retail fund to broaden its reach in the sector and funnel the cash raised into its $3.1 billion development projects.
It was raised in the merger documents with Federation, as a way to "recycle" non-core assets out of the new group's portfolio, but retaining a management presence.
Having had a bumpy start in the early stages as a merged entity, which saw a sudden change of chief executives, the new group, to be renamed Vicinity after a shareholder vote, has forecast a mixed, but steady outlook in retail sales.
The group will also focus on its $3.1 billion development pipeline.
Advertisement The highlights were the food-anchored centres and malls with international fashion brands, while the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for prescriptions hit chemists' turnover. Jewellery and other apparel were also hard hit.
Overall food and specialty stores, including giftware, pharmacy and cosmetics, pets, discount variety, tobacconists, florists and toys, were up 4.4 per cent in sales, while department and discount department stores were down.
However, the low Australian dollar has been an advantage, as there are fewer online sales and less overseas travel, meaning more domestic visitors to their local shopping centres.
The group's portfolio, which includes The Glen, Chadstone, which will have the first Legoland Discovery Centre in Australia, and Emporium, Melbourne and Chatswood Chase, Sydney, has high occupancy at 98.9 per cent.
Federation and Novion Property merged earlier this year, which under a scheme of arrangement required a vote of approval from Novion investors, but has seen a majority of Novion executives taking over from Federation staff.
That included at the top with Novion's chief executive, Angus McNaughton replacing Federation's Steven Sewell, together with the finance director Tom Honan, Mark Wilson and Kerrie Lavey​.
At the results on Wednesday, Mr McNaughton said direct comparisons for net profit were difficult, but the aggregated 2015 financial year underlying earnings were $683.1 million, up 6.2 per cent.
This is not comparable to the 2015 financial year forecast for Federation Centres.
A final distribution of 8.5¢ per security will be paid on August 27, taking the full year distribution to 16.9¢ per security.
While it was hard to make any comparisons with last year's earnings, UBS analysts said "all appears on track and confirms that there is nothing sinister from change in management".
"Given recent sell off post management change, relative valuation looks attractive, and likely to close post result," the analysts said.
Mr McNaughton said the results were boosted by the development pipeline, a focus on asset management and a "smooth" transition between the groups.
"The strategic focus or strategy of the business has not changed. We've already achieved over 60 per cent of our operational cost synergies on a run rate or annualised basis," he said.
On the proposed fund he said the group has long-term relationships with "some of the best investors in the market across the globe".
"One of the things we'll evaluate is whether we should take some assets off the balance sheet and set up an open-ended retail fund."
